zim.main package¶

Submodules¶

zim.main.command module¶

This module is responsible for commandline parsing. It provides a base class for the commandline commands defined in zim.main

class zim.main.command.Command(command, pwd=None)¶

Bases: object

Base class for commandline commands, used by zim to abstract part of the main() functionality and allow better testability of commandline arguments.

Sub-classes can define the options and arguments that they require. Then only the run() method needs to be defined to implement the actual command. In the run() method self.opts and self.args can be accessed to get the commandline options (dict) and the commandline arguments (list) respectively.

arguments = ()¶

Define arguments, e.g (‘NOTEBOOK’, ‘[PAGE]’)

default_options = (('verbose', 'V', 'Verbose output'), ('debug', 'D', 'Debug output'))¶
get_arguments()¶

Get the arguments, to be used by the implementation of run()

Raises

UsageError – when arguments are not correct

Returns

tuple of arguments, padded with None to correct length

get_options(*names)¶

Retrieve a dict with a sub-set of the command options

Parameters

names – that options in the subset

ignore_options(*options)¶
options = ()¶

Define options by 3-tuple of long, short & description.

parse_options(*args)¶

Parse commandline options for this command Sets the attributes ‘args’ and ‘opts’ to a list of arguments and a dictionary of options respectively

Parameters

args – all remaining options to be parsed

Raises

GetOptError – when options are not correct

run()¶

Run the command

Raises

UsageError – when arguments are not correct

Implementation

must be implemented by subclasses

class zim.main.command.GtkCommand(command, pwd=None)¶

Bases: zim.main.command.Command

Base class for commandline commands that result in a Gtk user interface being presented to the user or want to interact with the Gtk user interface.

If the run() method returns a window, it will be added to the application top level windows. And a Gtk.main loop will run until all windows are destroyed.

Commands derived from this class can be dispatched to the main application process. This is controlled by the standalone_process property.

NOTE: Do _not_ call Gtk.main from the command, this will be done by the application object.

default_options = (('verbose', 'V', 'Verbose output'), ('debug', 'D', 'Debug output'), ('standalone', '', 'start a single instance, no background process'))¶
run_local()¶

Method called in local process before we (try to) dispatch the command to the primary process. If it returns True we assume the command is done and run() is not called. If the command is called from the primary process directly, this method gets never called.

property standalone_process¶
exception zim.main.command.UsageError(msg, description=None)¶

Bases: zim.errors.Error

Error raised when commands do not have correct number or type of arguments

zim.main.ipc module¶

This module is responsible for the inter-process communication (ipc) between zim instances.

It provides low level functions to:

  1. Dispatching a list of commandline arguments to a socket

  2. Listening to a socket for commandline arguments. If recieved,

    a callback is invoked to handle those arguments.

zim.main.ipc.dispatch(*args)¶

If there is an existing zim process pass along the arguments

Parameters

args – commandline arguments

Raises

AssertionError – when no existing zim process or connection failed

zim.main.ipc.get_in_main_process()¶

Returns True if we are already in the main process

zim.main.ipc.set_in_main_process(in_main_process)¶

Set whether we are in the main process or not

zim.main.ipc.start_listening(handler)¶

Start listening to socket or named pipe for new commandline calls. Also sets current process to be the main process.

Parameters

handler – the method to call when new commands are recieveds

Module contents¶

This module defines the main() function for executing the zim application. It also defines a number of command classes that implement specific commandline commands and an singleton application object that takes core of the process life cycle.

build_notebook(ensure_uptodate=False)¶

Get the Notebook object for this command Tries to automount the file location if needed.

Parameters

ensure_uptodate – if True index is updated when needed. Only set to False when index update is handled explicitly (e.g. in the main gui).

Returns

a Notebook object and a Path object or None

Raises

  • NotebookLookupError – if the notebook could not be resolved or is not given

  • FileNotFoundError – if the notebook location does not exist and could not be mounted.

options = (('list', '', 'show the list with notebooks instead of\nopening the default notebook'), ('geometry=', '', 'window size and position as WxH+X+Y'), ('fullscreen', '', 'start in fullscreen mode'), ('standalone', '', 'start a single instance, no background process'))¶

class zim.main.HelpCommand(command, pwd=None)¶

Bases: zim.main.command.Command

Class implementing the --help command

optionhelp = "General Options:\n --gui run the editor (this is the default)\n --server run the web server\n --export export to a different format\n --search run a search query on a notebook\n --index build an index for a notebook\n --plugin call a specific plugin function\n --manual open the user manual\n -V, --verbose print information to terminal\n -D, --debug print debug messages\n -v, --version print version and exit\n -h, --help print this text\n\nGUI Options:\n --list show the list with notebooks instead of\n opening the default notebook\n --geometry window size and position as WxH+X+Y\n --fullscreen start in fullscreen mode\n --standalone start a single instance, no background process\n\nServer Options:\n --port port to use (defaults to 8080)\n --template name of the template to use\n --private serve only to localhost\n --gui run the gui wrapper for the server\n\nExport Options:\n -o, --output output directory (mandatory option)\n --format format to use (defaults to 'html')\n --template name of the template to use\n --root-url url to use for the document root\n --index-page index page name\n -r, --recursive when exporting a page, also export sub-pages\n -s, --singlefile export all pages to a single output file\n -O, --overwrite force overwriting existing file(s)\n\nSearch Options:\n None\n\nIndex Options:\n None\n\nTry 'zim --manual' for more help.\n"¶
run()¶

Run the command

Raises

UsageError – when arguments are not correct

Implementation

must be implemented by subclasses

usagehelp = 'usage: zim [OPTIONS] [NOTEBOOK [PAGE]]\n or: zim --server [OPTIONS] [NOTEBOOK]\n or: zim --export [OPTIONS] NOTEBOOK [PAGE]\n or: zim --search NOTEBOOK QUERY\n or: zim --index NOTEBOOK\n or: zim --plugin PLUGIN [ARGUMENTS]\n or: zim --manual [OPTIONS] [PAGE]\n or: zim --help\n'¶

class zim.main.NotebookCommand(command, pwd=None)¶

Bases: zim.main.command.Command

Base class for commands that act on a notebook

build_notebook(ensure_uptodate=True)¶

Get the Notebook object for this command Tries to automount the file location if needed.

Parameters

ensure_uptodate – if True index is updated when needed. Only set to False when index update is handled explicitly (e.g. in the main gui).

Returns

a Notebook object and a Path object or None

Raises

  • NotebookLookupError – if the notebook could not be resolved or is not given

  • FileNotFoundError – if the notebook location does not exist and could not be mounted.

get_default_or_only_notebook()¶

Helper to get a default notebook

get_notebook_argument()¶

Get the notebook and page arguments for this command

Returns

a 2-tuple of an NotebookInfo object and an optional Path or (None, None) if the notebook argument is optional and not given

Raises

NotebookLookupError – if the notebook is mandatory and not given, or if it is given but could not be resolved

class zim.main.ZimApplication¶

Bases: object

This object is repsonsible for managing the life cycle of the application process.

To do so, it decides whether to dispatch a command to an already running zim process or to handle it in the current process. For gtk based commands it keeps track of the toplevel objects for re-use and to be able to end the process when no toplevel objects are left.

  • kwargs – optional arguments for build_command
